awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: NSFGEO-NERC: The Origin of Aeolian Dunes (TOAD)
awd_abstract_narration:
Aeolian (wind-blown) sand dunes occupy 10% of the Earth's surface, both in vast desert sand seas and as important natural defenses against flooding along coasts. Despite extensive study of mature dunes, the question of "How do wind-blown dunes form?" remains unanswered, yet it is central to understanding dunes as major geological units, particularly given their increasing occurrence in desert regions of the United States and their adverse impact on water and vegetation supplies. This research will examine the key inter-relationships between airflow, surface properties, changes in sand transport and bedform shape that lie behind a meaningful understanding of how nascent dunes emerge. The project will promote international collaboration among the United States, the United Kingdom, and Namibia. It will generate public educational materials about desert landscapes and geomorphology, foster partnerships with National Parks in both the United States and Namibia, and provide quality scientific training and field experience to students.

Field monitoring of surface properties and bedform change at high resolution will be performed at three carefully chosen locations of known dune development. Complementary laboratory experiments will enable accurate characterization of flow very close to the 3D surface of modelled dunes that, together with the field datasets, will drive a computer model to test the sensitivity of dune initiation and growth to different controls in a range of environmental conditions in deserts, coasts and on other planets. In concert, this approach represents an opportunity to overcome an enduring plateau for understanding the origins of one of the major terrestrial landform systems. The team will work with staff at Great Sand Dunes National Park in the United States and the Namib-Naukluft National Park in Namibia to create broadly accessible public engagement materials. At a dedicated impact workshop in Gobabeb, Namibia, the team will showcase to interested local Namibian and international delegates the project findings and how these findings could be used to influence societal and economic issues. The project will engage undergraduate and graduate students in Namibia and give them valuable experience that could inspire them to pursue careers in science.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The principal aim of this study was to improve our understanding of how sand dunes are initiated and subsequently develop in their early stages of growth. Covering tens of thousands of square kilometers of Earth's surface, terrestrial dunes are an important and dynamic part of Earth's environment. Dune fields range in their age, from recent to millions of years, and through their stratigraphic record can embody an immense amount of information concerning past climates. In addition, dune fields can switch between active and inactive states based on the climate, and therefore their development can have major implications for land degradation, dust emission, and human infrastructure in desert environments. Furthermore, dunes have also been observed on other planets, such as Mars, and thus are a key source of information concerning the formative environments therein. However, our ability to interpret such data is dependent on a correct understanding of dune dynamics here on Earth. Although aeolian (i.e., wind-driven) sand dunes have been studied for many decades, and much has been observed and understood concerning the dynamics of mature, developed dunes and dune fields, far less is clear concerning the processes of their initiation and early-stage development. 

In particular, the interaction between atmospheric wind flow and the disturbance introduced by small deposits of sand, representing early stages of dune formation, has not received significant attention in past dune studies. Therefore, this project has aimed to shed light on these processes through targeted laboratory experiments, measuring the flow over representative "protodunes". This work has complemented experiments conducted by our collaborators studying similar dune forms in natural environments.  

Protodunes in nature are usually on the order of centimeters in height, and differ notably from mature dunes by exhibiting a reverse morphological asymmetry. This means that their gentler windward slope and steeper downwind lee side slope are reversed in their orientation compared to a mature dune. Understanding the initiation and early development of protodunes, and the evolution of mature dunes, could lead to the development of strategies to mitigate challenges such as land degradation, dust emission and dune impacts on human infrastructure in desert areas across the globe.  

However, it is a challenge to measure the entire flow field around a sand dune in the field, and even more so for small-scale bedforms. Therefore, the critical role of the laboratory experiments conducted hereim was to measure the flow and turbulence associated with dune morphologies in a scaled-down manner in a unique flow channel. This flow facility takes advantage of a refractive-index-matching technique, wherein the objects within the channel are rendered effectively invisible such that optical flow measurements can capture the critical near-surface regions of the flow relevant for sediment transport. The flow was captured using particle image velocimetry, an optical measurement technique wherein passive tracer particles in the flow are illuminated with a laser sheet and their reflections imaged with a camera or multiple cameras. Dune models were fabricated using idealized morphologies based on protodune topographies measured in nature, with the goal of reproducing their key physical characteristics: the shifting of the dune crest from an upstream to downstream position. Great care was taken to condition the flow to ensure appropriate similarity with the atmospheric surface layer flow that natural dunes are immersed within.  

Data indicate strong, topographically-induced, flow perturbations over the protodunes, to a similar relative degree as that found over mature dunes, despite their low-angled slopes. We find that the shape of the crest is an important factor in the development of flow perturbations, and only in the case with the flattest crest was maximal speed-up of flow, and reduction in turbulent stresses, found to occur upstream of the crest. Investigation of the log-linearity of the boundary layer profile over the stoss sides (an important metric for quantifying shear stress at the surface, as well as determining the equilibrium nature of the flow) showed that, although the profile is strongly perturbed, a log-linear region exists, but is shifted vertically within the flow. A streamwise trend in shear stress is thus present, showing a behavior similar to the trends in mean velocity. Analysis of the growth of the internal boundary layer on the upsteam stoss sides of the dunes, beginning at the toe region, reveals a similar development for all dune shapes, despite clear differences in mean velocity and turbulent stress perturbations in their toe regions. 

An additional contribution of the present work has also been to indicate key areas where further study of actual protodunes in nature is required. This includes the effects of saltation transport layers coincident with the flow, changes in the underlying substrate composition, and the impact of a rippled surface. Future studies may build on the foundation we have provided to fill in such remaining gaps in our knowledge towards a more comprehensive model of dune initiation and development.
